title: 105_hr4090
content: The Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998 authorizes the President to award a Medal of Valor to public safety officers for extraordinary acts of valor. The award is presented in the name of Congress based on the recommendation of the Medal of Valor Review Board. The Medal of Valor Review Board, established by the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various congressional leaders and the President. The Medal of Valor Review Board, established by the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various congressional leaders and the President. Three members are appointed by the President, with expertise in firefighting, law enforcement, and emergency services. Board members must have knowledge or expertise in public safety, serve a 4-year term, and meet at least twice a year. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Medal of Valor Review Board, established by the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various congressional leaders and the President. The Board shall conduct meetings at least twice a year, with the initial meeting to be held within 30 days of the last member's appointment. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business, and the Board may establish rules for its operations. The Board's duties include selecting candidates for the Medal of Valor from received applications, with meetings not to exceed once a year. The Medal of Valor Review Board, established by the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 1998, recommends Medal of Valor recipients to the Attorney General once a year. The Board can hold hearings, administer oaths, and pay witness expenses as needed. The Board can request information from Federal agencies to carry out its duties, and such information must be kept confidential to not compromise ongoing investigations or violate confidentiality laws. SEC. 4. BOARD PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Board members are compensated at a daily rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members who are government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing duties for the Board. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Public Safety Officer" and "State" are defined. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The Attorney General is authorized to appropriate necessary funds. SEC. 7. OFFICE. A national medal office is established within the Department of Justice to manage the Medal of Valor Review Board and nomination procedures. SEC. 8. CONFORMING REPEAL. Section 15 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is repealed. SEC. 9. CONSULTATION REQUIREMENT. The Attorney General must consult with the Institute of Heraldry within the Department of Defense on the design of the Medal of Valor, considering suggestions from the Department of Justice and external sources.
